title: HTML & Markdown
text:
HTML is a markup language that defines the structure of web pages, so understanding the HTML structure is essential for accurately extracting data during web scraping.

Understanding Tags and Hierarchy

Knowing the roles of HTML tags such as <div>, <span>, <table>, <ul>, and <li> makes it easier to locate the desired data.

You can use attributes such as id, class, name, and href to select specific elements.

Using XPath and CSS Selectors

Libraries like BeautifulSoup (Python) and rvest (R) use CSS selectors or XPath to find specific elements.

Example: soup.select('div.article > p') (BeautifulSoup) or html_nodes(doc, "div.article > p") (rvest)

Handling Dynamic Web Pages (Understanding JavaScript Rendering)

Some websites use JavaScript to load data dynamically, so tools like Selenium or Playwright are needed.





Markdown is mainly used for documentation, blog posts, and API docs, and you may need to handle it when extracting data from the web.

Handling Web Pages with Markdown

You may need to retrieve data stored in Markdown format from websites (e.g., GitHub, Jupyter Notebook, blogs) and convert it to HTML.

You might also need to restore Markdown after extracting only text from HTML using BeautifulSoup.get_text().

Cleaning and Converting Markdown Data

For example, you may need to crawl text saved in Markdown from a web page and convert it to another format (HTML, LaTeX, etc.).

You can use markdown2, mistune (Python), or markdown (R package) for conversion.

RMarkdown (.Rmd) is a document format that combines R code and narrative text.
Allows you to create documents with analysis results and interpretation together.
Output formats: HTML, PDF, Word.
Structure: YAML Header + Markdown Text + R Code Chunks

Writing a Practical Report

Key Components of a Good Report

Set title, author, and date using a YAML header

Include a table of contents (toc: true) and section numbering (number_sections: true)

Summarize data, visualize results, and report key statistics

Present conclusions and directions for further analysis



Example Report Template
YAML Header Example:
---
title: "Customer Data Analysis Report"
author: "Soonwon KWON"
date: "`r Sys.Date()`"
output:
  html_document:
    toc: true
    number_sections: true
---
Markdown Example:
## 1. Data Overview

This report presents an analysis of customer data.

```{r}
library(dplyr)
data <- mtcars %>% group_by(cyl) %>% summarise(avg_mpg = mean(mpg))
knitr::kable(data)
```

## 2. Visualization

```{r}
library(ggplot2)
ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = mpg, y = hp, color = factor(cyl))) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_minimal()
```

## 3. Conclusion & Insights

- Cars with a higher number of cylinders (`cyl`) tend to have lower fuel efficiency (`mpg`).  
- Further data collection and analysis are recommended.

text:
1. PPDAC Framework
(Problem, Plan, Data, Analysis, Conclusion)
The PPDAC framework is a representative statistical problem-solving framework that focuses on data-driven problem resolution.

PPDAC Process



Stage
Description




Problem
Define the statistical problem to be solved


Plan
Design the data collection and analysis methods


Data
Collect appropriate data


Analysis
Analyze the data using statistical methods


Conclusion
Interpret analysis results and make decisions





Key Features:

The most standardized statistical problem-solving process

Widely used in data analysis projects across various domains

title: Statistical Reasoning and Statistical Inference â€“ Utilizing Frameworks for Problem Solving
text:
2. GAISE Framework
(Guidelines for Assessment and Instruction in Statistics Education)
The GAISE framework is a step-by-step approach to statistical education proposed by the American Statistical Association (ASA).

GAISE Process







Stage
Description




Formulate Questions
Define the research problem


Collect Data
Gather relevant data


Analyze Data
Explore the data and apply statistical methods


Interpret Results
Make decisions based on the analysis results





Key Features:

Similar to PPDAC, but simplified to fit educational purposes

title: Statistical Reasoning and Statistical Inference â€“ Utilizing Frameworks for Problem Solving
text:
3. Data-Driven Decision Making (DDDM) Framework
The DDDM framework is a statistical approach to making decisions based on data analysis.

DDDM Process







Stage
Description




Identify Problem
Define the problem that needs to be solved


Collect & Prepare Data
Gather and preprocess relevant data


Analyze Data
Apply statistical methods and data modeling


Interpret & Apply
Make decisions based on analysis results


Monitor & Adjust
Continuously track data and optimize decisions





Key Features:

Used in business and policy decision-making

Relies on statistical methods for practical decision-making

title: Statistical Reasoning and Statistical Inference â€“ Utilizing Frameworks for Problem Solving
text:
4. Hypothesis Testing Process
Hypothesis testing is a process used to evaluate research questions through statistical inference.

Hypothesis Testing Steps







Stage
Description




State Hypotheses
Define the null hypothesis \((H_0)\) and alternative hypothesis \((H_1)\)


Choose Significance Level
Determine the significance level \((\alpha)\)


Collect & Analyze Data
Gather sample data and compute test statistics


Make a Decision
Conduct significance testing and either accept or reject the hypothesis


Interpret & Report
Apply the results to research or policy decisions





Key Features:

Applied in research and experimental design

Closely related to the analysis and conclusion phases of the PPDAC framework

title: Statistical Reasoning and Statistical Inference â€“ Utilizing Frameworks for Problem Solving
text:
5. Design of Experiments (DOE)
The DOE framework is a statistical approach to drawing conclusions based on experimental data.

DOE Process







Stage
Description




Define Objective
Establish experiment objectives and hypotheses


Design Experiment
Determine factors and levels for the experiment


Collect Data
Conduct the experiment and record data


Analyze Data
Evaluate factor effects using statistical tests


Draw Conclusions
Make decisions based on experimental results





Key Features:

Applied in industrial process optimization, A/B testing, and clinical trials

Similar to PPDAC but emphasizes an experimental approach

Description

title: Statistical Reasoning and Statistical Inference â€“ Utilizing Frameworks for Problem Solving
text:
Conclusion
PPDAC is the most general statistical problem-solving process, but different frameworks can be utilized depending on specific purposes such as education, business, experimental design, or machine learning.

Education and research purposes: GAISE, Hypothesis Testing Process

Business analysis and optimization: DDDM, DCOVA

Experiment and test-based analysis: DOE

Machine learning and data mining: CRISP-DM


In statistical problem-solving, PPDAC is the most versatile framework, but it is essential to use other frameworks as needed!

# season_dashboard.Rmd

## EPL Dashboard Overview

This dashboard, written in R using **RMarkdown + Flexdashboard + Plotly**, provides a visual summary of EPL standings for a given season and match type (All / Home / Away).

## How It Works

- CSV data is loaded directly from GitHub using the `params$season` and `params$type` values.

## Dashboard Layout

The dashboard consists of two columns:

### Left Column: Full Standings Table

- Displays the full league table using `DT::datatable()`
- Supports pagination and horizontal scroll for better viewing

### Right Column: Visual Analytics

#### 1. **Top 5 Teams by Points**

- Bar chart showing the top 5 teams
- Each bar includes a tooltip with:
  - Win / Draw / Loss record
  - GF, GA, GD values
- Points are labeled outside the bar

#### 2. **Points vs Goal Difference**

- Scatter plot comparing `Points` vs `GD` for all teams
- Color gradient represents `Pos` (position):  
  - `darkorange` for higher rank (lower number)  
  - `skyblue` for lower rank (higher number)
- Interactive tooltips show team names and key stats

## Parameters Used

```yaml
params:
  season: "2223"
  type: "All"
```

title: Static and Dynamic Web Crawling with R & Python
text:
Web crawling: Navigating and collecting data from across multiple web pages

Web scraping: Extracting specific information from a single page

Depending on the target, crawling is categorized as static (HTML-based) or dynamic (JavaScript-based)

title: Static and Dynamic Web Crawling with R & Python
text:
Static Web Crawling (rvest)

Use the rvest package to extract content directly from HTML pages

Functions like read_html(), html_nodes(), and html_text() help collect text, links, etc.

Tables built with <table> tags can be converted into data frames using html_table()

Use dplyr for cleaning the data and write.csv() to save it

title: Static and Dynamic Web Crawling with R & Python
text:
API-Based Data Collection (httr, jsonlite)

APIs provide structured data (JSON/XML) directly from the server

Use httr::GET() to request data and jsonlite::fromJSON() to parse the JSON response

API-based collection is faster and more stable than HTML scraping

You can extract fields like article titles, links, and dates, and save them as CSV

title: Static and Dynamic Web Crawling with R & Python
text:
Dynamic Crawling with JavaScript (RSelenium)

Pages rendered by JavaScript cannot be scraped using rvest

Use RSelenium to automate a browser and interact with JavaScript-based pages

Simulate user actions like clicking buttons, scrolling down, or handling infinite scroll

Requires setting up a web driver, and may depend on the system configuration

title: Static and Dynamic Web Crawling with R & Python
text:
Handling Login and Sessions (httr::POST())

Some websites require login before data can be accessed

Simulate login with httr::POST() and maintain session cookies

Note: Many modern websites use CAPTCHA or 2FA, so automatic login may be blocked

When possible, prefer official APIs with proper authentication

title: Static and Dynamic Web Crawling with R & Python
text:
Automation and Real-World Projects

To run crawlers regularly, you need automation tools

Linux: Use cronR; Windows: Use taskscheduleR

Example projects:

Daily crawling of trending news, saved to a cumulative CSV
Monitoring product price changes or trending keywords


When automating, also consider logging, date-tracking, and duplicate removal

title: Static and Dynamic Web Crawling with R & Python
text:
Key Takeaways

Static scraping: rvest, html_table, dplyr

API-based: httr::GET(), jsonlite::fromJSON()

Dynamic pages: RSelenium for JavaScript interactions

Login/session handling: httr::POST()

Automation: cronR (Linux), taskscheduleR (Windows)

All techniques come together in real-world data collection projects
